Sell a man a fish, get one-off revenue.
Teach a man to fish, lose a customer.
Give a man free fish as he implicitly sacrifices sovereignty over identity, attention, and descriptive data-- maximize shareholder value with low user acquisition costs.
Incentive problems are hard.

1064817402297442304.text: ... even though actual terms remain to be seen on Nov 27th, the existence of two for-profit vehicles (equity in Fifth Force Gmbh, the company being STO'd, and NEU tokens) should be a cause for concern. How will the upside of the Neufund platform be split between both instruments?

1064817400569360385.text: Using your own company as a testbed is double edged: if something goes wrong, it's less of a real problem (you won't sue yourself, for example), but the optics are bad anyway. Additionally ...

1064817399134867458.text: That should make it easier for Neufund to have their first STO be a success. You don't want your platform to flop its launch project when you know everyone will be looking. BUT.

1064817398073753600.text: On the plus side, there's 6M of capital basically sitting there and waiting for allocation options, as early withdrawals take a 10% haircut. Everyone that originally contributed capital was to a certain extent a fan of Neufund and they have made solid progress on their product.

1064817396454699009.text: Neumarks (the NEU tokens) were issued as a reward for these commitments and are security-like: they entitle their holders to dividends on the Neufund ecosystem. A very solid and rational model in my opinion.

1064817394609205248.text: The money (ballpark 12M then, 6M now) they raised during their "ICO" (termed ICBM) was not for them to spend. They raised the equivalent of an ecosystem fund. That money can then be spent by the original investors into STOs on the Neufund platform, or redeemed after 18 months.
